metadata.case_name: Rajah Velugoti Kumara Krishna Yachendra & Ors. v. Krishna Bahadur & Ors.

facts.text: The entire Venkatagiri Estate stood transferred to the Government and vested in it by reason of s. 3(b) of the Madras Estates Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari Act, 1948 from the notified date, i.e., September 7, 1949.

The Act received the assent of the Governor General on April 2, 1949 and some of its sections, including ss. 4 and 8, came into force at once. The other sections came into force with respect to the Venkatagiri Estate from the notified date.

Government deposited Rs. 12,11,419/- as advance payment of compensation, after deducting Rs. 7,28,500/- payable to the Government by the Estate for peishkush out of the sum of Rs. 19,39,919-8-0, half of the estimated amount of compensation payable.
Government also deposited as interim payment Rs. 1,55,194/- for each of the Fasli years 1359 to 1362 F.
In 1878, the estate had been made over to Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra, the eldest of the four brothers, by their father Kumara Yachendra Bahadur Varu.
Venkatagiri Zamindari was an impartible estate and succession to it was governed by the rule of lineal primogeniture.

In 1889, two of the brothers, Venkata Krishna Yachendra and Muddukrishna Yachendra, expressed a desire for the partition of the estate. The four brothers consulted their father who stated that the Venkatagiri Zamindari was originally acquired by the valour of ancestors, is ancient, impartible, passing by primogeniture, and not partible.

Document Exhibit A-1 (family arrangement in 1889): Venkatagiri Estate impartible, to be enjoyed by eldest son and line; allowances of Rs. 1,000/- per month to each of the three brothers and their male heirs; distributable per Hindu Law; ceases if branch extinct subject to widows' maintenance.
The document has been acted upon.
In 1904, the Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904 (Act II of 1904) came into force. Venkatagiri Estate included in Schedule, deemed impartible under s.3.
Rajah Velugoti Kumara Krishna Yachendra (Krishna Bahadur, appellant in CA 117/1961) filed OP No. 2300 of 1953 before Tribunal. His three sons filed separate petitions (appellants in CA 116,118,119).
Tribunal fixed Rs. 75,000/- as amount payable to Krishna Bahadur's branch out of Rs. 12,11,419/- advance payment; ratio 75:75:92 for Krishna Bahadur and two brothers of present Rajah in 1/5th.
None of contentions accepted by Tribunal or Special Tribunal on appeal.
Present Rajah (Sarvagna Kumara Krishna) filed CA Nos. 120-125/1961 challenging basis of maintenance calculation.
Appeals by special leave from judgment and decrees dated March 4, 1955, of the former Andhra Pradesh High Court in S.T. Appeals Nos. 83,85-88,90,91 and 119-121 of 1954.

legal_issues.text: Whether Venkatagiri Estate ceased to be impartible on notified date and compensation became partible among joint family.
Whether s.45 of the Act is ultra vires State Legislature for lack of competence or discriminatory under Art.14.
Whether claimants are sharers or maintenance-holders/creditors.
Whether peishkush deduction to be ignored in calculating maintenance from compensation.
Principle for calculating quantum of maintenance: proportion to 1889 income or per s.45.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to amount as sharers since impartible estate lost character from notified date; compensation partible; alternatively creditors.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.45 Madras Estates Abolition Act; Hindu Law joint family

petitioner_arguments.text: s.45 ultra vires: disturbs joint family rights; discriminatory (1/5th to maintenance-holders, 4/5th to proprietor/sons).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 21 List II vs Entry 7 List III GOI Act 1935; Art.14 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Maintenance not to be calculated after deducting peishkush; use full estimated Rs.19L not deposited Rs.12L.
Allowance is debt/creditor claim, not maintenance.

respondent_arguments.text: Maintenance quantum to bear same proportion to total compensation as Rs.1000/month bore to 1889 estate income (1/50th).
Act within legislative competence (acquisition); protected by Art.31B.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 9 List II GOI Act; Ninth Schedule

court_reasoning.text: Peishkush deductible; apportion net amount deposited (Rs.12L), as real compensation is value minus liabilities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal could not ignore deduction; s.54-A(2),(4)

court_reasoning.text: Allowance per Exhibit A-1 is maintenance, not debt; no purchase of shares; used dignified term, akin to maintenance claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not payable on loans; payable to males as maintenance allowance.

court_reasoning.text: s.45 valid: Act is compulsory acquisition (Entry 9 List II); not succession; Art.31B bars Art.14 challenge.
No need to decide if impartibility ceased post-notified date; rights cease on vesting (s.3); distribution per s.45; claimants not sharers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estate impartible till vesting; only s.45 rights thereafter.

court_reasoning.text: Maintenance per s.45(4),(5): not exceed 1/5th balance after creditors; no basis for 1889 proportion; Tribunal considers status etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.45(3),(5); Exhibit A-1 fixed after considering factors, not proportion.

holdings.text: Deduct peishkush for maintenance calculation; apportion deposited amount.
Claimants are maintenance-holders, not sharers or creditors.
s.45 intra vires; not violative of Art.14.
Compensation distribution per s.45; impartibility irrelevant post-vesting.
Apportionment per Tribunal correct; no 1889 proportion.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Estates Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari Act, 1948 (Madras Act XXVI of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs vesting, compensation deposit, apportionment among sharers/maintenance-holders in impartible estates.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904 (Act II of 1904)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined impartible estate; rights to maintenance; repealed for Venkatagiri post-notified date.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 challenge barred by Ninth Schedule; Act listed at item 10.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
sections: Seventh Schedule List II Entries 9,21; List III Entry 7

outcome.summary: All appeals (116-125/1961) dismissed; Tribunal's apportionment of advance compensation and interim payments upheld as per s.45; allowances are maintenance; s.45 valid; no shares to claimants; costs to respondents.
outcome.relief_granted: None; status quo from lower courts.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs, one hearing fee for CAs 116-119 and one for 120-125.

key_quotes.text: "the entire estate shall stand transferred to the Government and vest in them... all rights and interests... shall as against the Government cease and determine."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: s.3 consequences of vesting; limits claims to Act provisions.

key_quotes.text: "The allowance referred to in the deed, Exhibit A-1, as payable to Kishen Chander... is not akin to a debt owed by the Rajah to Kishen Chander. It is... payable for maintenance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Nature of allowance as maintenance, not debt.

key_quotes.text: "We therefore hold that the provisions of s. 45 of the Act are not void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds validity against Art.14 and competence.
